Title:
Muscodor brasiliensis sp. nov- isolated from Schinus
terebinthifolius and its inhibitory action against Penicillium
digitatum, the green mold agent in citrus
Keywords:
Biocontrol, Phylogenetic analysis, VOCs, endophytic fungi,
medicinal plant
Abstract:
The endophytic fungus Muscodor produces volatile organic
compounds (VOCs) with antimicrobial properties, thereby it is being
considered a promising alternative to biological control. Based on this,
this study aimed to isolate and characterize Muscodor strains from the
medicinal plant Schinus terebinthifolius and verify its action against
Penicillium digitatum, the causal agent of green mold in citrus. Two
strains, LGMF1255 and LGMF1256, were isolated and using morphological
data and phylogenetic analysis of ITS DNA region, were characterized as
belonging to Muscodor genus. The strain Muscodor sp. LGMF1255 presented
100% of ITS identity with M. sutura, M. vitigenus and M. equiseti. The
phylogenetic analysis suggests strain LGMF1256 as a new species, for
which we proposed the name of Muscodor brasiliensis. The VOCs produced
by both strains were identified and measured using SPME-GC-MS. Their
biological activities against P. digitatum were screened using different
nutritional sources. Both strains were able to inhibit P. digitatum
growth, but the results with M. brasiliensis were significantly higher,
and this strain was selected for enlarge the activity against P.
digitatum in fruit. The lesions of green mold were 67% smaller in
detached oranges when M. brasiliensis was present in comparison with the
control. The main VOCs produced exclusively by M. brasiliensis are
phenylethyl alcohol, α-curcumene and E (β) farnesene, compounds
previously associated with antimicrobial properties.
